facts.text: Canal restarted flowing on May 5, 1953; Shivlal allowed water despite not his turn.
On May 6, Shivlal's 6-hour turn from 8 a.m. to 2 p.m.; watered fields till 10:30 a.m., then diverted to fill village diggi with consent, promising rest later.
Diggi filled by 1 p.m. on May 7; Shivlal tried to divert water to fields, Bhagwandas prevented claiming his turn (actually after Surta).
Shivlal walked towards village; Bhagwandas hit him on head with kassi, Netram with lathi; both beat him; Mt. Rameshwari allegedly joined with wooden handle.
Incident witnessed by Hazari PW 3 grazing camels in Surta's field; he shouted, assailants fled leaving kassi.
Hazari revived Shivlal, helped him to Hukma's khala; left with Jora, Jagmal etc.; told them what he saw.
Shivlal taken to Raisinghnagar shop of Gyani Ram PW 4 by Bhaggu and Jagmal; told Gyani Ram of assault by Bhagwandas, Netram, Rameshwari over water.
Shivlal asked for son Ram Pratap and agent Ishardas; Ram Pratap arrived 6 p.m., Shivlal repeated story; taken to hospital at 5 p.m.
Shivlal died May 8 at 8:15 a.m.; 15 injuries, two grievous (sharp and blunt, fatal).
FIR by Ram Pratap based on Ex. P-1, recorded May 7, 7:30 p.m.
Dying declarations to Jora PW 7, Gyani Ram PW 4, Ram Pratap PW 5.
Sessions Judge acquitted all; High Court reversed for Bhagwandas and Netram, convicted u/s 302/34 IPC, life imprisonment; affirmed acquittal of Mt. Rameshwari.
Recovery of kassi, but not proved to belong to Bhagwandas.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was sufficient evidence against appellants to warrant conviction
Whether there were compelling reasons for reversal of Sessions Judge's acquittal

petitioner_arguments.text: No evidence against appellants sufficient to warrant conviction
No compelling reasons for reversal of acquittal judgment

respondent_arguments.text: Prosecution case supported by two eye-witnesses (Begaram PW2, Hazari PW3), dying declarations to three persons, recovery of kassi.

court_reasoning.text: Hazari PW3 testimony unreliable due to contradictions with Begaram, apparent tailoring to include Begaram; detracts materially from reliability, especially with acquittal of Mt. Rameshwari.
court_reasoning.key_observation: If Hazari mentioned Begaram merely because prosecution producing him, it detracts materially from reliability.

court_reasoning.text: Dying declarations to Gyani Ram PW4 and Jora PW7 suffer infirmities, material contradictions at various stages; Sessions Judge rejected them; not sure foundation if Hazari disregarded.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ordinarily dying declaration insufficient alone for murder conviction.

court_reasoning.text: Doctor's evidence makes improbable Shivlal walking or talking for declarations; High Court erred rejecting without putting medical texts to doctor.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Disapproved in Sundarlal v. State of MP.

court_reasoning.text: Kassi recovery neutral, not proved to belong to Bhagwandas.
Evidence such no tribunal could legitimately infer guilt; High Court judgment lacks substantial and compelling reasons to interfere with acquittal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Follows Surajpal Singh, Ajmer Singh, Aher Raja Khima.

holdings.text: Evidence insufficient; no legitimate inference of guilt; no compelling reasons to reverse acquittal.
High Court should not set aside acquittal without substantial and compelling reasons.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sundarlal v. The State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Disapproved judges relying on medical texts without putting to witness.
No grounds on evidence for conviction; set aside.
High Court not to set aside acquittal without compelling reasons.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ajmer Singh v. The State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court not to set aside acquittal without compelling reasons.

precedents_cited.case_name: Aher Raja Khima v. The State of Saurashtra
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court not to set aside acquittal without compelling reasons.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of murder with common intention

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court conviction of Bhagwandas and Netram, restored Sessions Judge's acquittal.

key_quotes.text: If as observed by the learned Judges of the High Court, Hazari had mentioned the presence of Bega merely because the latter was to be produced as a prosecution witness and because he (Hazari) had been asked to mention it, then it would detract so materially from his reliability that it would be dangerous to accept his testimony.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: there are here no grounds on the evidence, taken as a whole, upon which any Tribunal could properly, as a matter of legitimate inference, arrive at a conclusion that the appellant was guilty.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Privy Council to set aside conviction for insufficient evidence

key_quotes.text: This Court has held that the High Court should not set aside an acquittal unless there are substantial and compelling reasons for doing so.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle for appellate reversal of acquittal
